module.p: croit croft is a (feminine) toponymic common noun. It is a simple noun, with genitive singular croite and plural croitean.
croitear crofter is a (masculine) occupational common noun, derived from croit by means of the agentive suffix -(e)ar. The genitive singular form is croiteir, and the plural is croitearan.

Examples from modern usage –
’S e Tòmas an aon chroitear as aithne dhomh a dh’èirich gu inbhe taidhcùn. Rinn e sin tro dhìcheall, obair chruaidh agus tàlant malairt a bha neo-ghnàthach. An-diugh tha iomadh companaidh na ainm air feadh na Gàidhealtachd. [...]
Thomas is the only crofter I know who has risen to the status of a tycoon. He did that through duty, hard work and a talent for business that was unusual. Today there are many companies in his name all over the Highlands. [...] td. 5
croitearachd crofting, croftership is a (feminine) common noun describing an occupational activity, derived from croitear by means of the abstracting suffix -(e)achd.
cf. Coimisean na Croitearachd The Crofting Commission, known as Coimisean nan Croitearan until 2012.
